title: 114_s2873
content: The Act is titled the "Expanding Capacity for Health Outcomes Act" or the "ECHO Act." It defines terms like health professional shortage area, Indian tribe, medically underserved area, and medically underserved population. The curr_chunk defines terms such as "Native Americans," "Secretary," and "technology-enabled collaborative learning and capacity building model." The curr_chunk discusses the examination of technology-enabled collaborative learning models and their impact on addressing various health issues and workforce shortages. It also defines the term "tribal organization" in relation to the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The curr_chunk discusses the implementation of public health programs, delivery of healthcare services in underserved areas, and consultation with stakeholders on technology-enabled learning models in healthcare settings. The Secretary is required to address various health issues and workforce shortages within 2 years. The Secretary must submit a report to specific committees and post it online within 2 years, detailing findings on technology-enabled collaborative learning models in healthcare and their impact on provider retention, especially in shortage areas. The report will detail the impact of technology-enabled collaborative learning models on provider retention in shortage areas, including quality of care, access to care, barriers to adoption, effects on practice scope, and cost-effectiveness of the models. The report will include a list of technology-enabled collaborative learning models funded by the Secretary in the past 5 years, recommendations to reduce barriers for using such models, opportunities for increased adoption in existing Department of Health and Human Services programs, and suggestions for incorporating these models into medical education and lifelong learning. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
